verses.text: Thus the heavens and the earth were finished, and all their multitude.
verses.comment: Opens with the completion of creation. The mention of 'multitude' highlights God's sovereignty over all creation, setting the stage for mankind's place within it.

verses.text: On the seventh day, God finished His work that He had done, and He rested on the seventh day from all the work that He had done.
verses.comment: The introduction of the seventh day marks the origin of rest, a practice later foundational to worship and liturgy. This foreshadows the calling of a holy day for God's people.

verses.text: So God blessed the seventh day and made it holy, because on it God rested from all His work that He had created and done.
verses.comment: God's blessing and sanctification of the seventh day draws a spiritual parallel to the future eternal rest in union with Him, as discussed in Hebrews.

verses.text: These are the generations of the heavens and the earth when they were created. In the day that the LORD God made the earth and the heavens,
verses.comment: "Generations" here means 'origins' or 'history.' The phrase signals a transition to the account focusing on mankind.

verses.text: before any plant of the field was yet in the earth, and before any herb of the field had sprouted—for the LORD God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was no man to work the ground,
verses.comment: Describes a time before agriculture and rain, emphasizing humanity's key role as caretaker and co-worker with God.

verses.text: but a mist would go up from the earth and water the whole face of the ground.
verses.comment: Alternative translation could be 'stream' or 'spring.' The text highlights the divine provision for creation even before humans act.

verses.text: Then the LORD God formed the man from dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and the man became a living being.
verses.comment: The intimate act of forming man from dust is both literal and a type for Christ, the second Adam (1 Cor. 15:45). The 'breath of life' speaks to the soul as a unique spiritual reality.

verses.text: And the LORD God planted a garden in Eden, in the east, and there He put the man whom He had formed.
verses.comment: God prepares paradise for man, showing God's intention for man to dwell in intimate fellowship with Him.

verses.text: And out of the ground the LORD God made to grow every tree that is pleasing to the sight and good for food. The tree of life was in the middle of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
verses.comment: Trees signify not only physical sustenance but spiritual realities. The tree of life reappears in Revelation, alluding to eternal union and restoration.

verses.text: A river went out of Eden to water the garden, and from there it was divided and became four branches.
verses.comment: The sources of life and blessing in Eden prefigure the rivers of grace pictorially represented in Ezekiel and Revelation.

verses.text: The name of the first is Pishon. It is the one that flows around the whole land of Havilah, where there is gold.
verses.comment: The specifics evoke the richness and goodness of God's original creation; Havilah's gold is also described as good.

verses.text: And the gold of that land is good. Bdellium and onyx stone are there.
verses.comment: Precious stones here anticipate their later use in worship, suggesting a connection between creation and worship.

verses.text: The name of the second river is Gihon; it is the one that flows around the whole land of Cush.
verses.comment: Specific geography remains uncertain, but the idea highlights the abundance and provision flowing from Eden.

verses.text: The name of the third river is Tigris, which goes east of Assyria. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
verses.comment: These rivers correspond with known rivers, grounding the paradise account in real geography.

verses.text: The LORD God took the man and put him in the garden of Eden to work it and to keep it.
verses.comment: 'Work' and 'keep' also describe priestly functions in later texts, hinting at man's sacred vocation as steward.

verses.text: And the LORD God commanded the man, saying, 'You may surely eat from every tree of the garden,
verses.comment: God's command offers great freedom, with only a single limitation—showing His generosity and the importance of obedience.

verses.text: but from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, you must not eat, for in the day that you eat from it you shall surely die.'
verses.comment: The command sets up the moral test. Spiritual death as separation from God enters here, pointing forward to the need for redemption.

verses.text: Then the LORD God said, 'It is not good that the man should be alone. I will make a helper suitable for him.'
verses.comment: Refers to the complementary nature of man and woman. The term 'helper' does not imply inferiority but mutual support and partnership.

verses.text: Now out of the ground the LORD God had formed every animal of the field and every bird of the sky and brought them to the man to see what he would call them. And whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name.
verses.comment: Naming is an act of authority, symbolizing dominion and responsibility. Adam as the first steward participates in God’s ordering of creation.

verses.text: So the man gave names to all cattle, to the birds of the sky, and to every beast of the field. But for Adam there was not found a helper suitable for him.
verses.comment: Despite creation’s fullness, God’s plan for companionship and love points ahead to the marriage covenant.

verses.text: So the LORD God caused a deep sleep to fall upon the man, and he slept; and He took one of his ribs and closed up the flesh in its place.
verses.comment: The creation of woman from man’s side signifies equality and unity. This foreshadows Christ and His Bride, the Church, born from His side pierced on the cross.

verses.text: And the rib that the LORD God had taken from the man He made into a woman and brought her to the man.
verses.comment: Emphasizes both the unity in origin and dignity of man and woman. God Himself brings the woman, blessing the first union.

verses.text: Then the man said, 'This one, at last, is bone of my bones and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called Woman, because she was taken out of Man.'
verses.comment: Adam's poetic response reveals the mystery of marital union, later reflected by Paul as a type of the union between Christ and the Church.

verses.text: Therefore a man shall leave his father and his mother and hold fast to his wife, and they shall become one flesh.
verses.comment: Foundational text for marriage as a sacramental covenant, pointing ahead to the indissoluble union of Christ and His people.

verses.text: And the man and his wife were both naked and were not ashamed.
verses.comment: Their innocence reveals God’s original intent of harmony without shame; a state restored by grace after redemption (see parallels in Rev. 3:18).
